title: 114_s1011
content: The Act may be cited as the "State Trade and Export Promotion Utilization Program for American Small Businesses Act" or the "STEP UP for American Small Businesses Act". It focuses on state trade and export promotion. The Small Business Act is amended to include a State Trade and Export Promotion Grant Program for eligible small business concerns in the United States. The Small Business Act is amended to include a State Trade and Export Promotion Grant Program for eligible small business concerns in the United States. Eligible businesses must meet specific criteria including being in business for at least 1 year, being export ready as determined by the Associate Administrator, and having access to resources for exporting and doing business with foreign purchasers. The State Trade and Export Promotion Grant Program supports small businesses in the US by covering costs related to exporting, such as packing, shipping, freight forwarding, and customs brokers. Definitions for terms like 'program', 'rural small business concern', 'socially and economically disadvantaged small business concern', and 'State' are provided in the Small Business Act. The State Trade and Export Promotion Grant Program, established by the Associate Administrator, provides grants to States to assist small businesses in participating in foreign trade missions, sales trips, accessing Department of Commerce services, and covering website translation fees. The State Trade and Export Promotion Grant Program, established by the Associate Administrator, provides grants to States to assist small businesses in participating in various export initiatives such as website translation fees, international marketing media design, trade show exhibitions, training workshops, reverse trade missions, procurement of foreign consultancy services, and other initiatives determined appropriate by the Associate Administrator. Grants may also be provided to States to increase the number of eligible small businesses that export and to increase the value of exports by eligible small businesses. The Associate Administrator may prioritize grants for export programs that focus on eligible small business concerns, including socially and economically disadvantaged, women-owned, and rural small businesses. The Associate Administrator may prioritize grants for export programs that focus on eligible small business concerns, including socially and economically disadvantaged, women-owned, and rural small businesses that promote exports from states with lower export percentages. Activities with high return on investment and adoption of shared best practices are included in the grant criteria. The Administration limits states to one grant application per fiscal year. Grants to top 10 states with high small business exporters cannot exceed 40% of program funds. The Associate Administrator will award grants under the program for a maximum of 2 years. States must submit an application with required information and consult with trade agencies to avoid duplication before applying. The Associate Administrator will award grants under the program on a competitive basis. The Federal share of the cost of an export program carried out using a grant shall be determined based on the State's export volume. The Federal share of the cost of an export program using a grant will be 65 percent for high export volume states and 75 percent for others. The non-Federal share must be at least 50 percent cash and no more than 50 percent indirect costs and in-kind contributions. Reports must be submitted within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Associate Administrator must submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business and Entrepreneurship after the Act's enactment. The report should include the program's structure, management plan, and merit-based review process. Additionally, the Associate Administrator must publish an annual report on the Administration's website. The Administration must submit an annual report on the program, detailing the number and amount of grants awarded, states receiving grants, activities performed with each grant, the impact on exports by small businesses, and the total return on investments. The annual report on the program includes details on grants awarded, states receiving grants, activities performed, impact on small business exports, and best practices by states with high returns on investment. The Associate Administrator notifies relevant committees when the report is published. The Inspector General of the Administration conducts reviews on the performance and management of grants under the program. Reports are submitted to the Committee on Small Business. The Inspector General of the Administration conducts reviews on the performance and management of grants under the State Trade and Export Promotion Grant Program. Reports are submitted to the Committee on Small Business. Entrepreneurship of the Senate and the Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives receive a report on the review. Authorization of appropriations is set at $30,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2016 to 2020. Membership of Representatives of State Trade Promotion Agencies on Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee is amended. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) includes representatives from state trade promotion agencies appointed by the President for a 2-year term. These members serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee (TPCC) members are allowed travel expenses, including per diem, while away from their homes or regular place of business. The Secretary of Commerce provides administrative assistance, including a security clearance, as needed. The TPCC members are entitled to travel expenses and administrative assistance from the Secretary of Commerce.
